krispyjala wrote:
> Hi J.B.,
>    Because I want to test what happens if I pass in a null into my
> method.  My method does certain business logic and I want to test
> that it handles null properly.  So, in reality if the method's not
> private, I would be able to call this:
> 
> String abc = "hello";
> myMethod(null,abc);
> 
> so I want to see whether of myMethod throws the correct exception.
> 
> When using PrivilegedAccessor.invokeMethod, then, I need to pass the
> two parameters of null and abc as an Object array for its third
> argument.  Does that make sense?

Yes. You seem to be doing what I would be doing. The problem with 
passing null as the first parameter is that PrivilegedAccessor does not 
know what /type/ null is, so it can't match the method signature. At 
least, that's what I'm guessing. Is there a two-step process for using 
PrivilegedAccessor where you get the method first (passing in Class 
objects for the parameter types), /then/ invoke the method? If so, I'd 
try using that.
